results.title: Dinosaurs
results.creator_credit: Steve Skok, Curriculum Branch, Ministry of Ed, Schools Div, Victoria and Peter Bence
results.brief_description: Fossil records show that the dinosaurs were an enormously successful group containing many species. This program examines the reasons why they were so prolific and discusses some of the theories behind their disappearance.

results.title: Dinosaur tracks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Johnson and friends”.
Johnson and his friends get together in six stories. In “Diesel tries to fly” all the toys are put in danger as Diesal tries out his wings. Squeaky’s good at guarding the bedroom but what about the “Dinosaur tracks”? Is Johnson falling apart as the toys follow the mysterious “Pink thread.” “Melissa’s dinosaur”, Victoria is introduced to the toys. In “Diesel who?”, the toy loses his memory after a nasty crash. McDuff feels very superior after a visit to the toyshop, and the toys try to get her back to her old self in The Homecoming.

results.title: Dinosaur junction series
results.brief_description: This video contains three short episodes of ‘Dinosaur Junction’ which uses animated dinosaurs to illustrate in a fun way how children can learn to cope with problems they face such as peer pressure and fighting. ‘Doin’ it you way’ looks at decision making and peer pressure; ‘The fight’ looks at controlling your temper and dealing with anger; ‘What’s in a name’ looks at self esteem and fitting in. Suitable for Primary level students.

results.title: Dinosaur
results.creator_credit: Will Vinton and Will Vinton Productions
results.brief_description: Clay animated figures and simple chalk line drawings are transformed into awe-inspiring prehistoric animals in this interpretation of our earth as it existed long before man. A fastpaced motivating introduction to dinosaurs and their prehistoric world, suitable for children of all ages.

results.title: Dinner for two
results.creator_credit: Barrie Angus McLean, ONF | NFB and Janet Perlman
results.brief_description: Peace in the rainforest is disrupted when two chameleons get “stuck” in a conflict, with catastrophic results. Luckily for the lizards, a frog observing the fracas turns into exactly what they need…(no, not a prince)…a mediator. “Dinner for two” tackles conflict in lively, humorous and provocative ways. It shows that amidst the chaos that differences create, there are still paths to reconcilliation. This animated film without words is designed as a flexible tool to explore conflict resolution. Young children to senior executives can identify with the characters, and gain an insight into how to deal creatively with conflict and anger at school, at home, in the workplace and in their communities.

results.title: Dinner at the Homesick Restaurant [a discussion]
results.creator_credit: Daryl Wayland, Country Education Project, TV Ed Productions and David Zweck
results.brief_description: Jocelyn Terry leads a discussion with Val Kent of Huntingdale Technical School and Dr. Alan Diknot of Monash University to provide some explanations of the puzzling aspects of Anne Tyler’s novel. The program discusses why the novel opens with Pearl’s death; our sympathy for Pearl and for Beck; the effect of their upbringing on the children; and the role of the subsidiary characters.

results.title: Dinner at school
results.creator_credit: Seven League Productions and H.M. Nieter
results.brief_description: Stresses the desirability, during World War II, of a hot midday meal for school children, and shows what was done in Great Britain to make such a meal available, free of charge or at a very low cost.

results.title: Dinner at eight
results.creator_credit: David O. Selznick, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and George Cukor
results.brief_description: Lionel Barrymore and Billie Burke play the Jordans, a shipping magnate and his wife, who are planning a dinner party and invite several interesting people. The complex plot gets underway as we get to know the invited guests and learn about their lives, their joys, their problems and their tragedies. Adapted from the play by George S. Kaufman and Edna Ferber.

results.title: Dinnawan the emu
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday, Jean Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Wild Life”.
The emu, found only in Australia, is second in size to the ostrich. Like the ostrich it is unable to fly, but with its long and powerful legs is able to run at great speeds. Traces the history of the emu from when it roamed over the whole continent and Tasmania. European settlement has led to the extermination of the emu except in Central Australia. Shows laying of eggs, the male emu keeping the nest, hatching chicks and two years growth to full size.

results.title: Dinky Hocker
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America, Robert Guenette, Diane Asselin, Paul Asselin and Tom Blank
results.brief_description: Portrays the plight of a girl who is addicted to food and whose mother is too busy to be concerned. In the face of her mother’s opposition to her attempts at dieting and with the friendship of a young man who shares her addiction, Dinky makes one last attempt to gain her mother’s attention. Based on the book “Dinky Hocker Shoots Smack” by M.E. Kerr.
